abstract.p: Psychologist Joseph A Hirsch letter holds that interactive Web sites for children will enrich entrepreneurs, not young people they serve (June 6 article)

block.p: ''For Not-Ready-for-MySpace Girls, Dress-Up and Diversions on the Web'' (Business Day, June 6) attests to the further depersonalization of human interactions that I see as a psychologist.
''For Not-Ready-for-MySpace Girls, Dress-Up and Diversions on the Web'' (Business Day, June 6) attests to the further depersonalization of human interactions that I see as a psychologist.

Virtual reality is not the same as healthy fantasy. Rather, it is socially isolating. On the other hand, play with one's peers is an important activity in the social and emotional development of all mammalian species, not the least of which are humans.

A large part of my clinical practice is devoted to the treatment of young people who complain of loneliness and social anxiety. Too intimidated to talk in person, some of these very same individuals are quite conversant in electronic communication (text messaging, e-mail) and overindulge in the use of the Internet.
Beginning this process in underdeveloped children will enrich the Web site entrepreneurs, not the children they serve.
Joseph A. Hirsch New York, June 6, 2007
